Award.AwardTitle: Fiber Lasers for Coherent Raman Microscopy

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0967949
Wise

Coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering (CARS) microscopy is a sensitive and label-free nonlinear imaging technique that is attracting much interest. The technique requires an excitation source that provides two temporally-synchronized and wavelength-tunable picosecond light pulses. Existing sources of such pulses are complicated, expensive, and require trained operators, and these features create a major barrier to prospective users of CARS microscopy. A group from Cornell University will develop fiber-based light sources that promise to be integrated, stable, compact, and user-friendly. These will facilitate the expansion of CARS and related microscopy techniques beyond specialized research laboratories. The Cornell group will collaborate in the development with a group from Harvard University that is a leader in CARS microscopy. The generation of high-energy and wavelength-tunable picosecond pulses from an all-fiber source is a major challenge. New understanding of ultrafast nonlinear pulse propagation, and new ways to control ultrashort light pulses, will have to be developed in order to demonstrate the proposed capabilities. This will be converted into designs of short-pulse oscillators, amplifiers, and frequency-conversion stages. The development of such instruments is central to the fiber optics and ultrafast optics communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientists are developing new kinds of microscopes designed to be able to image deep in tissue.  These new microscopes use ultrashort light pulses to illuminate the sample, and detect light produced at new colors through interaction with the tissue, or fluorescence emitted by the tissue.  Raman imaging is a technique that is based on the generation of new colors of light. Lasers that produce the ultrashort light pulses (flashes of light that only last a millionth of a millionth of a second) exist, but they are designed for use in science research labs. For the new Raman microscopes to have broad impact (in imaging facilities, surgical suites, etc.), compact lasers that are extremely stable and reliable have to be developed.  Lasers based on optical fiber can provide the needed practical attributes, but they have not been able to generate the high-power short light pulses needed by the new microscopes.

Graduate students working on this project figured out how to design fiber lasers that can generate the high-power pulses.  This required developing some new understanding of the physics of short light pulses going through fiber.  That understanding allowed the students to build fiber lasers that match the performance of the lasers in the research labs, but with the major practical advantages of fiber (an example laser is shown in the first figure).  After the lasers were shown to provide good performance, the students took them to the laboratory of experts in biological imaging at Harvard University.  The new lasers were tested there, and they produced excellent images. An example is shown in the second figure: white matter in a sample of a mouse brain was imaged with one of the new microscopes outfitted with a new fiber laser. The lasers that were developed in this work provide the best performance reported so far for fiber lasers. 

New concepts for high-performance short-pulse fiber lasers were demonstrated in this project.  The results are promising enough that a couple companies are considering making commercial versions. This is needed for instruments to really have an impact on a field.  The initial results demonstrated in this project indicate that someday, this type of laser and microscope might be used to image human tissue, such as in brain surgery, for example.  

This NSF grant provided financial support for two graduate students.  Both students have completed their PhD degrees and taken positions as postdoctoral scientists.
